results.title: The Life that lives on man
results.creator_credit: Michael Andrews and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Skin, for all its accessibility is one of the least studied organs of the body. Looks at the whole ecology of bacteria, yeasts and animals, which are a human being’s intimate companions through life.

results.title: The Frustrating fours and fascinating fives (Colour)
results.creator_credit: Judith Crawley, National Film Board of Canada and Crawley Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
A study of the behavior of four-and-five-year-old children at home and at nursery school. At four the vacillation between infantile helplessness and vigorous self-assertion is seen, and at five the development of independence and the beginning of cooperation. Parents observe that, unpredictable as their behavior may be, it’s fun to help in the development of the fours and fives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judith Crawley, National Film Board of Canada and Crawley Films

results.title: He acts his age
results.creator_credit: Judith Crawley and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
How a child’s emotional development normally keeps pace with their physical growth; the behavior they exhibit at certain ages. This introductory film examines the play habits of children from one to fifteen years of age and shows the characteristics of each group.

results.title: Stephanie
results.creator_credit: Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
The film gives insights into Stephanie’s strategy for coping with a physical handicap. Her attitude towards others with intellectual and physical handicaps is revealed in her interactions with her sister at home and with handicapped children who visit her school.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: If at first you don't succeed: you don't succeed [Colour version]
results.creator_credit: Peter Goodchild, Edward Goldwyn and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
If a mother does badly in bringing up her child in the first 5 years of his life, then the child has almost no chance of success in school. Child psychologists can now measure a new-born baby’s capacity for solving complex problems and they have found that the infant’s motivation is the sheer joy of solving the problems, but if the potential is not developed the damage is irreversible. The results of this research are having major implications for education.
results.title_for_label: If at first you don’t succeed: you don’t succeed [Colour version]

results.title: The Teens
results.creator_credit: Edmund Reid, National Film Board of Canada and Crawley Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
A film appraisal of the typical behaviour of three teenagers in the everyday life of an urban family. Two boys and a girl demonstrate in their attitudes and actions the basic similarities of teenagers of the ages thirteen and fifteen and, at the same time, the individual differences deriving from their developing personalities. The age of adolescence, is a time of adjustment during which the buoyancy of youth is moulded into the more mature forms of adulthood.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edmund Reid, National Film Board of Canada and Crawley Films

results.title: The Other way
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents the ideas of E.F. Schumacher, a British economist who is deeply concerned with dwindling fuel supplies, myths about modern technology, and the loss of human worth in 20th-century consumer production. Emphasises his idea that many modern machines use too much energy and that there is a need to develop an intermediate technology of machines that consume less energy. Commentary by Ian Holm.
